taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Latin, echinus , sea urchin, alluding to spiny tips of receptacular paleae]

bio:treatment.discussion: In keys and descriptions, “discs” refers to receptacles at late flowering with paleae and florets included in assessing shapes and in measurements of lengths and diameters.

key_statement.description: Basal leaves: blades (1–)5–12 cm wide, bases rounded to cordate (plants fibrous rooted)
Basal leaves: blades 0.5–4(–6.5) cm wide, bases usually cuneate to attenuate, sometimes rounded ( E. laevigata ) (plants taprooted).
Herbage (stems and leaves) glabrate (and glaucous); basal leaf blades 3–6.5 cm wide, margins usually serrate or dentate
Herbage usually sparsely to densely hairy, rarely glabrous; basal leaf blades 0.5–4 cm wide, margins usually entire.
Hairs (stems, leaves, and peduncles) appressed to ascending.
Rays yellow; s, c Missouri, n Arkansas (Ozark region)
Rays pale pink, dark pink, purple, or white; Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas.
Ray laminae 19–35 mm; ray cypselae glabrous distally; e Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas
Ray laminae 30–70 mm; ray cypselae hairy distally (at least on angles); s, c Oklahoma (Arbuckle Mountain region)
Discs 20–35 mm diam. (herbage induments relatively harsh); widespread, plains,w North America
Discs 15–25 mm diam. (herbage induments relatively soft); c Tennessee
Discs subspheric, 15–30 × 20–30 mm; paleae 8–11 mm, tips purple, rounded (sw Arkansas, w Louisiana, se Oklahoma, e Texas)
Discs conic to hemispheric, 20–40 × 20–37 mm; paleae 9–14 mm, tips pinkish to purple, sharp-pointed.
Ray corollas pink to reddish purple, 3–4 mm wide; pollen usually white, some-times lemon yellow; cypselae glabrous
Ray corollas rose to pink or white, 4–7 mm wide; pollen yellow; cypselae (rays) hairy (n Arkansas, se Missouri, eastward)
